The constant depletion of fossil feedstock, combined with their enormous impact on environmental health, has pushed the scientific community toward the definition of alternative energy sources. In this context, hydrogen has emerged as the elective “green choice”. Despite its huge potential as a sustainable fuel, its production remains an issue. In this context, liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) are considered a viable alternative for the safe transport and in-situ production of hydrogen. In the present work, we report the achievements obtained on the generation of hydrogen from formic acid (FA), exploiting a bis-imidazolium Pd(0) based supported catalyst. The herein developed system proved to be particularly suitable in an aqueous environment due to its stable porous structure while demonstrating remarkable efficiency at high FA concentration (2.5 M) and under basic conditions, especially when NaOH was exploited to reach pH 9. These findings contribute to giving further insight into the correlation between catalyst structure and reactivity. The heightened activity in an alkaline environment was also a key aspect for a notable enhancement in the dehydrogenation rate, avoiding the possible dehydration pathway, which is generally favored at lower pH values. The sustainability of both the process and the catalyst has been further validated through its capacity for reusability, which has demonstrated consistent efficiency over five consecutive runs. Introduction Nowadays, modern society is increasingly struggling with the high energy demands and the need to reduce fossil feedstock dependence, thus aspiring to a “green transition”. This step is even more fundamental if we concretely look forward to mitigate the adverse effects of GHG (Greenhouse gas) emissions on people and environmental health [1]. In this context, research on alternative energy sources is becoming essential for future energy management. This is even more true and urgent considering the challenging goals set by several countries, such as the United States [2] and the European Union [3], that fixed 2050 as the year of “net zero emissions of greenhouse gases”. In the last decades, different routes and strategies have been pursued to find the best green alternatives, such as geothermal power, wind power, solar energy conversion, and biomass utilization. None should be considered the best solution, but it is better to consider them all synergistically. All these energy sources have reached the efficiency to satisfy about 24 % of the total energy demand [4]. Unfortunately, despite their enormous potential, they suffer from some limits; for example, they are strongly geographically dependent and naturally intermittent [5]. For example, many countries can exploit geothermic power, such as Iceland or Kenya [6], while these cannot take advantage of dedicated energy crops useful for biodiesel production as, for example, rapeseed oil, which is preferably cultivated in the western part of the U.S.A., some parts of Central Europe, and Central Asia [7]. Furthermore, renewable energy has to be efficiently stocked and provided rapidly in a reversible manner to balance fluctuations in supply and demand [8,9]. For these reasons, hydrogen (H2), if adequately produced, is considered an optimum green energy source whose manufacturing is not limited by geographical or natural issues. In addition to being the most abundant element in the universe, hydrogen is an inexhaustible source of energy. In its molecular form, hydrogen possesses extremely interesting physical and thermodynamic values. For example, its heating value (HV) is between 141.8 MJ/kg and 120 MJ/kg at 298 K, which is largely higher than that of gasoline (44 MJ/kg at 298 K) [10]. Unfortunately, to date, H2 production is not fully sustainable, and the different methodologies adopted have been recently classified according to their cleanness using a colour code (grey, blue and green), considering both the hydrogen sources and their overall life cycle assessment [11]. Grey hydrogen is produced starting from oil-derived fuels such as natural gas [12]. Although blue hydrogen is produced similarly to grey hydrogen, using fossil fuels, it does not imply the CO2 emission but rather its inclusion. Finally, green hydrogen, which is what most scientific efforts are looking for, is typically made by exploiting both renewable power supplies and feedstocks. To access green H2 water electrolysis [13,14], biomass gasification [15,16] or alcohol steam reforming [17,18] are promising approaches. It is worth mentioning that hydrogen is not exempt from other drawbacks, again derived from its intrinsic chemical-physical characteristics. It is extremely flammable and, when mixed with air, can result in the formation of an explosive blend [19]. Besides this, its liquefaction is highly dangerous and expensive, considering that boil-off events could happen, too. This poses serious safety issues, counting that large tanks to store H2 gas are necessary to obtain an accessible quantity of energy. For these reasons, it becomes apparent that power generation, storage, and transportation are some of the great goals that the scientific community must achieve urgently if it aims to transition toward a non-renewable fuel-free society. In this context, liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) represent a viable solution for storing and releasing hydrogen on demand [20]. Above all, LOHCs can be easily transported, stored, and used at lower cost and significantly reduced risks compared to both liquid and compressed hydrogen [21]. In the last few years, among the most studied LOHCs, we can find naphthenic hydrocarbons [22], nitrogen-substituted heterocyclic aromatics [23], isopropanol (i-PrOH) [24], methanol (MeOH) [25,26] and formic acid (FA) [27,28]. While H2 production from the dehydrogenation of naphthenic hydrocarbons and nitrogen-substituted heterocyclic hydrocarbons usually requires harsh conditions, dehydrogenation of formic acid is, in contrast, advantageous in terms of costs, efficiency and environmental impact [29]. More in detail, FA came into the limelight as a promising biobased-derived LOHC because of its high hydrogen content (4.4 wt %), which means 53 g H2/L or 43.8 g H2/kg, which can be released via dehydrogenation reactions [30-33]. It is a highly desirable substance for hydrogen storage and transportation due to its stability at room temperature, limited flammability range (between 18- 57 % by volume), and limited toxicity. These properties make FA a safe and practical option for storage and transportation purposes [34-36]. Industrially, it is mainly produced through a waste-free method that provides the carbonylation of methanol followed by hydrolysis of the methyl formate to access FA and MeOH [37]. Recently, with the aim to set up a synthesis as green as possible, limiting harmful emissions, FA can be efficiently produced starting from bioderived feedstock, including dehydration-oxidation and cleavage of waste glycerol or hydrolysis followed by dehydration of hexoses [20]. Hydrogen generation from LOHCs has been mainly focused on the use of homogeneous catalysts. These, despite their excellent stability and efficiency, are not always suitable for scale-up processes, which are fundamental for the high energy demand nowadays required [38]. Homogeneous catalysts, generally considering their nature, necessitate the use of solvents or additives and additional steps for their recovery [28]. On the contrary, heterogeneous catalysts can be easily recovered from the reaction mixture and reused, a feature that can counterbalance their lower efficiency. In recent years, several heterogeneous catalytic systems have been developed for FA dehydrogenation [39,40] using, for example, monometallic catalysts based on Pd or Au [41-43], bimetallic such as PdAg or PdAu [44,45] and trimetallic catalytic systems composed for example by NiAuPd or IrPdAu [46,47]. Moreover, metal-oxides based catalysts [48,49] and Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) [50], have recently gained interest and have been extensively adopted for H2 production starting from formic acid. In this scenario, carbon-supported palladium catalysts have also attracted considerable attention because of their potential to facilitate hydrogen production from FA dehydrogenation [26,39,51,52]. In the present contribution, we tested the efficiency of a class of polymer-supported heterogeneous catalysts decorated with highly versatile pincer-type ionic tags that can stabilize both Pd(II) anionic complexes [53] or Pd(0) nanoparticles [54-56]. These catalysts showed excellent performance in different types of reactions, such as cross-coupling [57], C–H activation [58], and biomass hydrogenation [59]. Within this investigation, after a proper cross-linker and ionic-tag selection, the dehydrogenation of FA was carried out using a tailor-made bis-imidazolium Pd(0) based catalyst (POLITAG-20-Pd(0)) supported on a macroreticular resin (20 % of cross-linking), i.e. a polymeric matrix characterized by a well-developed and durable porous structure, even in a dry state. Unlike gel-type resins, macroreticular polymers possess a higher cross-linking degree, avoiding the necessity of an appropriate solvent to gain access to their inner active sites. Indeed, given the permanent reticular structure, macroreticular resins are particularly suitable for catalytic applications also in aqueous media. This latter is of high interest since, as it is well known, high pH values favour FA dehydrogenation into H2 and CO2, completely inhibiting the dehydration process that usually occurs under acidic pH (Fig. 1 ) [60,61]. Furthermore, the enhanced catalytic activity under basic pH suggested the presence of a correlation between structure and reactivity. Experimental section General remarks Unless otherwise stated, all chemicals were purchased and used without any further purification. Styrene (contains 4‑tert-butylcatechol as stabilizer, ≥ 99 %), NaCl (≥ 99 %), polyvinyl alcohol (MW 13.000–23.000, 89% hydrolyzed), toluene (≥ 99.5 %), AIBN (98 %), cyclohexanol (99 %), THF (≥ 99 %, contains 250 ppm BHT as inhibitor), n-hexane (≥ 99 %), NaH (60 %, dispersion in mineral oil), DMF (anhydrous, ≥ 99.8 %), methanol (≥ 99.8 %), acetone (≥ 99.5 %), iodomethane (> 99.7 %), PdCl2 (99.9 %), ethanol (absolute, ≥ 99.8 %) and NaBH4 (powder, 98 %) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. 4-Vinylbenzylchloride (90 %) was purchased from Acros Organics. AIBN was recrystallized from methanol before use. 4-Vinylbenzylchloride and styrene were extracted three times with a 10% w/w NaOH solution and filtered through an Al2O3 pad to remove the polymerization inhibitor. GLC analyses were performed by using Hewlett-Packard HP 5890 A equipped with CarboPLOT P7 (25 m, 0.53 mm, 25 µm) capillary column, a Restek methanizer for Agilent GCs, a FID detector, and helium as gas carrier. Elemental Analysis (EA) was conducted on Elementar UNICUBE® elemental analyzer. Metal loading was measured using MP-AES 4210 instrument. TEM images were obtained using a PHILIPS CM 12 transmission electron microscopy operating in the range 20–120 kV with an image resolution of 0.34 nm. The XRD patterns were collected in the on a PANalytical X′PERT PRO diffractometer, PW3050 goniometer, equipped with an X′ Celerator detector by using the Cu Kα radiation. The synthesis of SPACER cross-linker [62] and 3,3-bis(1 H-imidazol-1-yl)propan-1-ol ligand (L) [53] was performed as described in previously reported work (Fig. 2 ). Synthesis of the macroreticular polymeric support SP-20-Cl A three-neck cylinder-shaped glass vessel equipped with a mechanical stirrer, a condenser, and an argon inlet was charged with an aqueous NaCl (9.30 g, 6 wt%) solution (150 mL) containing polyvinyl alcohol (MW 13.000–23.000, 89% hydrolyzed, 2.30 g, 1.5 wt%) and deoxygenated by purging with argon. After 6 h, a mixture of 4-vinylbenzylchloride (3.40 g, 22.5 mmol), toluene (1 mL), and AIBN (0.06 g, 0.37 mmol, 2% wt) was rapidly added to the solution and the mixture heated at 85 °C for 30 min. A solution of 1,4-bis(4-vinylphenoxy)benzene (SPACER) (2.01 g, 6.4 mmol, 22% wt) in 20 mL of cyclohexanol/toluene (1:1) was added dropwise and the mixture kept under stirring at 85 °C for additional 24 h. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the polymer beads were isolated by filtration, washed with water (50 mL) and then extracted by using water (100 mL), THF (100 mL), and n-hexane (100 mL) in a Soxhlet apparatus. Finally, the resin SP-20-Cl was dried under vacuum for 15 h (5.06 g, 92% yield). Synthesis of the macroreticular polymeric support POLITAG-20-L In a 25 mL two-neck round bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer, ligand 3,3-bis(1 H-imidazol-1-yl)propan-1-ol (0.40 g, 2.1 mmol), and NaH (0.36 g, 4 eq, 60% oil dispersion,) in 10 mL dry DMF were placed at 0 °C under argon atmosphere. The mixture was heated to room temperature and SP-20-Cl resin (0.87 g) was added. After 1 h, the temperature was increased to 60 °C and the mixture was left under stirring for 16 h. The solid was filtered, washed with milli-Q water, THF, MeOH and acetone, and then dried under vacuum for 24 h. The amount of ligand per gram of resin was measured by elemental analyser (C: 72.96, H: 6.894, N: 7.17, loading: 1.28 mmol/g). 1.00 g of the obtained SP-20-L intermediate was added in a stainless-steel vessel, equipped with a magnetic stirrer, in presence of 5 mL of iodomethane. The mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 20 h. After cooling to room temperature, the mixture was filtered and the POLITAG-20-L supports washed with MeOH and acetone, and finally dried under vacuum to afford a yellow solid. Bis-imidazolium ionic tags loading was determined by elemental analysis (C: 54.60, H: 5.463, N: 4.59, loading: 0.82 mmol/g). Synthesis of POLITAG-20-Pd(0) In a 20 mL round bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer, POLITAG-20-L support (600 mg) was placed in 5 mL of water. A solution of Na2PdCl4 (1.2 eq.), prepared in situ from PdCl2 (1.2 eq) and NaCl (20 eq) in 10 mL water at 80 °C, was added dropwise at 28 °C to the suspension and the mixture was kept under stirring for 2 h. The solid was filtered under reduced pressure and washed with water and methanol and finally dried under vacuum. The resulting POLITAG-20-Pd(II) (400 mg) was then suspended in 10 mL anhydrous ethanol at 0 °C and a solution of NaBH4 (7 eq.) in 5 mL of anhydrous ethanol was added dropwise with. The reaction mixture was kept under stirring for 2 h at 28 °C, then filtered under reduced pressure, washed with methanol and ethanol, and dried under vacuum. Palladium loadings in POLITAG-20-Pd(0) was measured by MP-AES analysis (7.27 wt%, 0.68 mmol/g) Typical procedure for FA dehydrogenation In a round bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a gas burette filled with water to measure the volume of released gases, the catalyst (44 mg, 1.2 mol%), FA (115 mg, 2.5 mmol) and H2O (1 mL) were consecutively added, and the resulted mixture was left under stirring at 90 °C for 200 min. The reaction course and the gas composition were determined through gas chromatographic analysis over the reaction time. General procedure for catalyst recycling In a round bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a gas burette filled with water to measure the volume of released gases, the catalyst (44 mg, 1.2 mol%), FA (115 mg, 2.5 mmol) and H2O (1 mL) were consecutively added, and the resulted mixture was left under stirring at 90 °C. After 100 min (t 50 %), the dehydrogenation gas composition was analysed through a gas chromatographic analysis, and a fresh reaction mixture was consecutively added to the catalyst in the reaction flask. Results and discussion Herein are reported the main data obtained during formic acid dehydrogenation using a Pd(0) based polymeric heterogeneous catalyst. The process under investigation has been properly examined, and different reaction parameters, such as temperature, reaction time, FA concentration, pH, and the base adopted, have been varying. Furthermore, to enhance the process conceptualization and sustainability, a catalyst recycle study has been carried out, revealing the robustness of the tailor-made catalytic system. FA dehydrogenation Once the macroreticular Pd(0) supported catalyst (Fig. 2) was prepared, its activity for H2 generation from FA dehydrogenation in aqueous media was evaluated. The catalyst behaviour for hydrogen production was initially investigated by screening the temperatures. As reported in Table 1 , starting from an FA aqueous solution of 2.5 M at pH 9 and 3 mol% of catalyst, we managed to obtain a promising conversion of 49 % at 90 °C after 200 min (Entry 2). On the contrary, when the reaction temperature was decreased to 60 °C, only traces of the dehydrogenation products were detected (Entry 1), while when raised to 120 °C, no appreciable improvements in H2 production were noted. It is noteworthy that extending the reaction for a longer time did not affect FA conversion (Entry 4). Based on these preliminary data, we decided to test the dehydrogenation efficiency by modifying the catalyst amount, leaving the reaction temperature at 90 °C. Reducing the catalyst amount from 3 to 1.2 mol% improved FA dehydrogenation (Entry 5 and 6), permitting an 88 % conversion after 400 min. This behaviour can be expected, considering that it is not unusual to observe a negative mass transfer effect when using high catalyst loading [64]. On the other hand, reducing the catalyst amount to 0.8 mol % did not furnish satisfactory results (Entry 7 and 8). To give further insight into the process under investigation, the role of FA molar concentration on its decomposition was investigated. Taking as a reference point the best reaction condition so far found, Fig. 3 shows that the 2.5 M formic acid solution resulted the most efficient. Both increasing or reducing FA concentration led to a lower H2 formation per volume of formic acid used. This result is highly remarkable, considering that most of the works already published usually exploit highly diluted concentrations [65-67]. Subsequently, a pH screening, as well as the role of the base adopted, was investigated. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , at 90 °C using the optimized amount of catalyst (1.2 mol %), the best results in terms of conversion after 200 min were obtained at pH 9. Similar results were obtained at pH 11, while at higher or lower values, an important reduction of dehydrogenation rate was detected. These findings validate the developed protocol, highlighting that under these conditions, total selectivity toward the dehydrogenation process was achieved while inhibiting dehydration, which is usually favoured under acidic environments (vide supra). GLC analysis performed using a methanizer directly linked to the gas chromatograph revealed only the presence of CO2 gas. At the same time, no traces of CO were detected, confirming the involvement of the sole dehydrogenation pathway under the optimized conditions. As regards with the base adopted, NaOH resulted in the most effective, validating the fundamental role of sodium to favour Pd-catalysed hydrogen transfer (Fig. 5 ), which is on the contrary, hampered by larger counterions, such as K+ or NH4 + [59]. The poor results in terms of conversion obtained using our homemade Pd(0) catalyst at strong acidic pH suggest a crucial role of the ionic interaction between formate and the ionic environment around Pd(0). Consequently, a plausible formic acid dehydrogenation mechanism has been proposed (Scheme 1 ). To deepen the study conducted, the dehydrogenation efficiency of a formic acid/ formate salt mixture was investigated as well. As reported by Yurderi and colleagues [68], the presence of formate salts, especially sodium formate (SF), can promote the catalyst activity, enhancing the dehydrogenation rate. Under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 2 ), the best results in terms of hydrogen production were obtained using FA as the sole source of hydrogen. Actually, when FA was used in combination with both one and three equivalents of SF, no decomposition traces were detected. On the contrary, a not negligible 50 % conversion was detected when using sodium formate as hydrogen source avoiding the use of FA, while just a slight 35 % conversion when employing ammonium formate. Catalyst recovery and recycle In the perspective of developing a process as sustainable and cost-effective as possible, the catalyst reusability evaluation is essential. Indeed, it resulted efficient in FA dehydrogenation for more than 5 consecutive runs, without any loss of activity. To extensively stress the catalytic system, the FA decomposition reactions were performed for 100 min., instead of the typical 200 min., considering the t50 % conversion (Fig. 6 ). TEM analysis further confirmed the high catalyst efficiency and stability, elucidating the preservation of Pd nanoparticle morphology and dimensions of the recycled catalyst (Fig. 7), in comparison with the fresh one (see Fig. 2). Finally, the performances of our catalytic system were further compared to representative literature examples (Table 3 ). The differences in TOF values are generally due to the remarkable disparity in terms of experimental conditions. However, what actually defines catalyst efficiency is not only limited to catalytic activity parameters; on the contrary, it should also be ascribed to the H2 gas productivity expressed as g/L. Indeed, even if formic acid has a hydrogen content of 53 g/L, the high dilution generally adopted during the catalytic experiments dramatically reduces hydrogen production. In this context, the herein-developed catalyst presents notable advantages compared to other Pd-based heterogeneous catalysts due to its good efficiency at high formic acid concentration. Conclusions In conclusion, a pincer-type Pd(0) catalyst supported over a macroreticular resin was prepared, and its catalytic efficiency over formic acid dehydrogenation was investigated. The best catalytic performance was observed when the FA decomposition was performed at 90 °C, using NaOH as a base at pH 9. These findings proved to be fundamental for the decomposition course in the presence of Pd(0) stabilized by pincer-type ionic tags. As properly reported in literature, the alkaline pH value favours the dehydrogenation hampering FA dehydration. Under the optimized reaction condition a satisfactory 70 % conversion of FA into H2 and CO2 gases was achieved after 200 min reaction, without revealing any traces of CO. This confirms the highly selective protocol developed. In addition, the proposed catalytic system allowed us to reach these good results working in 2.5 M concentration. Striving to create a highly efficient system for hydrogen production, catalyst recovery and reuse were investigated. Evaluating formic acid conversion at t50 %, the catalyst adopted was efficient for more than five consecutive runs, showing just a slight loss of efficiency. Further studies will be conducted to solve the drawbacks observed and enhance the catalytic activity toward the dehydrogenation reaction. coredata.dc:description: The constant depletion of fossil feedstock, combined with their enormous impact on environmental health, has pushed the scientific community toward the definition of alternative energy sources. In this context, hydrogen has emerged as the elective “green choice”. Despite its huge potential as a sustainable fuel, its production remains an issue. In this context, liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) are considered a viable alternative for the safe transport and in-situ production of hydrogen. In the present work, we report the achievements obtained on the generation of hydrogen from formic acid (FA), exploiting a bis-imidazolium Pd(0) based supported catalyst. The herein developed system proved to be particularly suitable in an aqueous environment due to its stable porous structure while demonstrating remarkable efficiency at high FA concentration (2.5 M) and under basic conditions, especially when NaOH was exploited to reach pH 9. These findings contribute to giving further insight into the correlation between catalyst structure and reactivity. The heightened activity in an alkaline environment was also a key aspect for a notable enhancement in the dehydrogenation rate, avoiding the possible dehydration pathway, which is generally favored at lower pH values. The sustainability of both the process and the catalyst has been further validated through its capacity for reusability, which has demonstrated consistent efficiency over five consecutive runs.
